title: 105_s2355
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truancy Prevention and Juvenile Crime Reduction Act of 1998". Congress finds that truancy is a significant issue, with many negative consequences such as increased likelihood of dropping out of school, higher rates of criminal behavior, and a correlation with daytime burglary and vandalism. Additionally, a high percentage of violent juvenile crimes occur during school hours, and a large number of children arrested for crimes are truants. Some cities report as much as 70% of student absences are unexcused, with up to 4,000 absences per day in a single city. Truancy among children aged 13-16 is a significant issue, with up to 75% of those arrested for crimes being truants. Cities report high rates of unexcused student absences, reaching 4,000 per day. The social and economic costs of truancy are substantial, with truants and high school dropouts costing the nation $240 billion in lost earnings and foregone taxes. Effective prevention and intervention programs can improve school attendance and reduce daytime crime rates. The cost of truancy is significant, with truants and dropouts costing $240 billion in lost earnings and foregone taxes. Effective prevention programs are lacking targeted funding in current law. SEC. 3. GRANTS. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like "eligible partnership," "local educational agency," "qualified unit of local government," and "unit of local government." These definitions are crucial for understanding the eligibility criteria for partnerships and government units applying for grants. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will make competitive grants to eligible partnerships to reduce truancy and daytime juvenile crime. The maximum grant amount is $100,000 per fiscal year, with at least 25% allocated for use by local educational agencies. Grants can be renewed under certain conditions. Grant amounts under this section shall not exceed $100,000, with at least 25% allocated for local educational agencies. Grants can be renewed for up to 2 additional fiscal years. Funds can be used for truancy prevention activities such as parental involvement, sanctions for habitually truant students, parental accountability measures, and in-school prevention programs. The curr_chunk discusses measures for addressing truancy, including driver's license suspension, parental accountability, in-school prevention programs, involvement of various community entities, technology use, and eliminating incentives for truancy. The Attorney General may prioritize funding for model programs like the Truancy Intervention Project in Fulton County, Georgia. The Attorney General may prioritize funding for model truancy intervention programs such as the Truancy Intervention Project in Fulton County, Georgia, the TABS program in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the Roswell Daytime Curfew Program in New Mexico, and others across different states. The Attorney General may prioritize funding for model truancy intervention programs in various states, including projects like the Atlantic County Project Helping Hand in New Jersey, the THRIVE initiative in Oklahoma City, and the Grade Court program in Farmington, New Mexico. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2001 for these programs.
